turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in two cases that have been consolidated for argument: No. 97-1927, Rodney C. Hanlon, et al. v. Paul W. Berger; and 98-83, Charles H. Wilson v. Harry Layne.
Mr. Cordray.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
I represent the Marshals Service officers in Wilson and all the officials in Hanlon.

There are two issues in these cases: the constitutional issue itself and the further issue of whether in any event these officers should be held personally liable for money damages when, at the time they acted, the law was not clearly established and it was not apparent that their conduct violated the Fourth Amendment.
We submit that however the Court decides the constitutional issue is a matter of first impression in this case.
Mitchell v. Forsyth compels the result that qualified immunity should be upheld for these officers here.

Turning first to the constitutional issue, as framed by the Court, the issue is whether law enforcement officials violate the Fourth Amendment when they permit members of the news media to accompany them in order to observe and report on their execution of a warrant.
We submit that it would be wrong to erect a per se rule that in all circumstances such conduct is improper.

Certainly to the extent that the search in the Hanlon case involved open fields or had the arrest of Dominic Wilson occurred in a public place, it would be unproblematic that the media accompanied the officers and observed and reported on their execution of a warrant.

As a larger matter, moreover, there are many instances throughout this country every day in which third parties accompany officers as they execute warrants, and this has been true since the inception of bench warrants.
There are many different circumstances.
They may be there to join in performing the search or the seizure in assistance of the officers.
They may assist the officers in other more tangential ways: provide clerical help, translating, identifying evidence.
They may also help facilitate the law enforcement objectives that are served by procuring and implementing the warrant itself.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let's... let's get to the help that you claim was provided here.
What's your argument here?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Your Honor, as reflected in the Justice Department policy in the U.S. Attorneys' Manual in effect at the time of the Hanlon search and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It has since been... that section has since been repealed.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Since been amended.
That's correct.
Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Amended out of existence as I recall.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: No.
Modified.
Modified with respect to the execution of a warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How does it read now?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: It... it still is the case... this is set forth in the appendix to the blue brief in the... in the Hanlon case... that law enforcement officers may assist the news media in reporting on and observing and videotaping--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does it say that they may take members of the media into people's houses, into private places--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --It doesn't speak to that, but it has now specified that they should not facilitate media accompaniment in the execution of a warrant, Your Honor.
However, at the time the policy certainly countenanced such conduct and, in fact, encouraged it.

However, the purposes served are the same ones that were served as... as stated in that policy, which are to promote the aims of law enforcement by deterring criminal conduct and by enhancing public confidence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, why do you have to take photographers into someone's house to aid law enforcement in that respect?
I mean, you can have a news conference when it's over if you want to.
I don't see why you... you have to take people into private places.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: This Court has held that the Fourth Amendment doesn't require a least intrusive means test as long as the conduct is reasonable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.
I just want to know whether there's anything substantial to this or whether it's... whether it's fluff.
It sounds like fluff.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Well certainly, Your Honor, to the extent that the media are permitted to give a firsthand objective account of the actual events, that facilitates accurate reporting on law enforcement functions, and it may be quite helpful in preventing abuses in instances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But why just the media, Mr. Cordray?
Do... do you know of any other area of law in which the... the media, quotes, have been given special constitutional privileges that... that John Q. Public wouldn't have?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: No, Your Honor, and no one contends that the media should have special privileges here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, they could have brought in maybe their sister-in-law to... to watch the thing too as well.
Is that... is that it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Many law enforcement departments around the country do have a public ride-along program that will permit public to ride along with officers and observe--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do they drive right into the house?
Yes, right into the house or... or inside premises on a search warrant or... or is the program more one of letting them ride in squad cars and see whatever occurs on the street?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Well, there are a variety of such programs, and I'm sure that in various circumstances--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you know of any that allow private citizens to accompany officers inside dwellings to execute a search warrant?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Well, yes, Your Honor.
The Marshals Service policy at issue in the Wilson case in place at the time clearly countenanced... page 7 of the joint appendix--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but your argument was that there were... there were... throughout the country, there was a practice of ride-along, and our question is do they ride right into the house.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
We... we have--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you have specific instances in which this is going on?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --We have... we have cited to the Court the Fletcher case from the Florida Supreme Court which recognized, as a matter of common usage and custom at the common law as of 1972, that it was common practice to allow media to accompany police--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --even into private property or residence--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think the question... excuse me.

I think the question that we're... we're pursuing is, are individuals other than those in the media going into people's houses for the execution of warrants in a capacity simply as observers, not performing any law enforcement function?
And I... I think we got... several of us I guess got the suggestion from you that the answer to that was yes, and we want to know whether that is specifically correct.

Is there a practice out there in the country, apart from the Marshals Service, of taking members of the public, performing no law enforcement function, into private places during the execution of a warrant?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --That's where I beg to differ.
The purpose of a public ride-along program, as with the media ride-along program, is to serve law enforcement purposes.
That's the whole... it's not merely for someone's entertainment value or to satisfy someone's curiosity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right.
We'll... we'll accept that qualification.
Are members of the general public going into people's houses during the execution of the warrants?
Is this a common practice?
We'd just like to know that.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I... I can't speak to that one way or another, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you have any instances?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I can speak to the fact that it was recognized at the common law as of 25 years ago, that it was common practice around the country for the media to accompany--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cordray--
--For media to accompany, but not for private individuals.
As far as you know, it is not and has never been common practice for police officers to bring in non-media people to show that... that everything is open and above board.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I... I can't speak to that one way or another, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Can you answer my question?
As far as you know, there was no such practice.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I believe that's right, but I wouldn't want to concede that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you know... do you know of any... do you know of any such practice?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I know that there are public ride-along programs.
I'm sure they have different components.
I don't know for certain that they contemplate entry into a home, but they do contemplate the public attending or accompanying officers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I... may I ask you specifically about the law school program?
There are law schools that do have their students ride along.
Indeed, some of them have had professors who have written books about their ride-along experiences.
Are there controls on that kind of ride-along to avoid the unnecessary intrusion on people's privacy?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I'm certain that they are, just as a matter of common sense practice and to avoid potential lawsuits and the like.
I can't at firsthand speak to law school programs around the country, but I do believe that they are fairly common.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the... in the Montana case, there was no entry into the house by virtue of the warrant.
Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: That's correct.
There was no execution of the warrant in the home.
The only entry into the home was accompanying Mr. Berger--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By consent?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --By consent to explain the situation to his wife so there wouldn't be a misunderstanding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there was an entry into sheds and outbuildings, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: With regard to those, does the evidence disclose whether those buildings had open doors or anything like that or... or what do we know about those sheds and outbuildings?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: The search in the Hanlon case was executed in two different places, in open areas on the ranch, which I think fairly clearly would fall within the open fields doctrine, although it is private property, and at the same time in outbuildings.
And the record, as... as far as I can tell, does not disclose for certain one way or the other whether they were within the curtilage or not.
But they may well be.
I think there is a constitutional argument that they are open fields--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that issue wasn't resolved below because it was a... pretty much a per se rule applied, I take it.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I think that's right, both ways, by the district court in our favor and by the court of appeals--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you understand the open--
--You don't really know whether open... whether sheds, closed sheds at least, that are outside the curtilage come within the open fields doctrine.
We haven't... we haven't held one way or another on that point, have we?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I don't believe the Court has specified all the details of that, no.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you don't understand the... or maybe you do... the open fields doctrine to permit a police officer to stay on an open field if the owner tells him to leave, do you?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: As I understand the open fields doctrine, it would because the Court has said that searches of open fields, even though they may be private property, do not implicate the Fourth Amendment.
And, therefore, I... I think that that's correct, although again I don't believe the Court specifically addressed that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But in the... in the Oliver case, the Court was referring to the fact that officers happened to be in an open area and they were concerned with viewing something in an open field from a highway.
But in... in... in this case, the police and the accompanying news people demanded, in effect, entrance and had the right to enter under a warrant--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and... and threatened the owner with... with imprisonment if... if he obstructed their search.
So, it seems to me that's quite different.
I... I'm not sure the open fields doctrine would apply if you told the police officer to leave.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think it's an open factual issue in this case, and I think what's germane to the issue that the Court has framed is that there was no execution of a warrant in a home in that case.
And if this Court is particularly concerned with execution of a warrant in a home, that would not be implicated on the facts of the Hanlon case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, supposing there's a policeman that's standing out on your front lawn, and you tell him, get off, and he says, no, I want to look in your window.
[Laughter]
I mean, is that a trespass violation or a Fourth Amendment violation or what?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: As here, the police are operating pursuant to a valid warrant, and it's been determined in both cases that they were properly executing the warrant.
In a... in a situation where the police are looking through a window, they may or may not have right to be at the vantage point they're at--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think that bears on the open... open fields question.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --It may.
It may, and again I think that's an open factual issue in this--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why do you need a warrant under the open fields doctrine?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I think you would not need a warrant, although perhaps in an abundance of caution to avoid any problems that might arise in later litigation or motion to suppress, certainly the better practice would be for the police to obtain a warrant, as they did here.
But in any event, to return to the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, just because the police can... can play around in open fields, it doesn't mean that they can bring along anybody else they want to play in the open fields.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --No, but certainly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, I mean, even if you resolve the open field question, there's still the further question of whether whatever open fields immunity from the Fourth Amendment the officers have extends to the... the officers bringing along somebody else as well I assume.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I think that's correct, but that's why I thought it was important to emphasize the Court should not erect a per se rule against media accompaniment in all circumstances where a warrant is involved.
In many instances, a warrant would be executed in such a way as to not even implicate Fourth Amendment interests.
It might be executed in a public place.
It might be executed in an area of open fields.

Certainly the nature of the intrusion is much reduced in that setting, and... and across the board, across the spectrum of different possible settings, each of them somewhat fact-specific, each of them raising maybe a greater or lesser extent of intrusion, those are factors that would be relevant in trying to draw this balance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But as you put it, we shouldn't adopt a rule regarding media accompaniment.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, it is... it is part of your case that... that... that there's a... a different rule for media, and that... and that it's... it's better to bring media along than to bring your sister-in-law.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think it's... it's more... more beneficial in certain respects and it's more of a concern in certain respects.
The Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Personally I'd rather have your sister-in-law along than--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Perhaps.
The Court framed the issue in terms of media, but in general the Court... the Court has... has... has never addressed the issue of any third parties coming along.
We don't contend that the media have a special, privileged constitutional right of access.
They do not under this Court's case, but they as surrogate for the public could potentially be... they should not be discriminated against.
It's not as though the media should be the one individual not permitted to do what private individuals might otherwise be permitted to do--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --It's fairly common, isn't it, Mr. Cordray, to bring along the claimant to stolen property with the search so that he... it's his property presumably if they're successful, and he should identify it?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
There are a variety of practices where third parties are permitted to accompany police and have been thought to be without problematic discussion reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But those are to aid in the specific search, not for some more systemic purpose of criminal administration.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: In many cases, that's true, but there are also a number of instances in which that really can't be maintained.
For example, in the Hanlon case, the assistant prosecutor, Kris McLean, accompanied the officers.

It wasn't contended that he was helping to execute the particular search, but he was there serving the same objectives for which the officers had sought and obtained a search warrant in the first place to enforce the Federal wildlife laws.
He was probably going to be prosecuting any charges that might be brought, and it was thought it would useful for him to attend and observe the execution of the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, wouldn't there be... wouldn't there be some purpose too to take along someone who was a lawyer in case you run into some uncertain Fourth Amendment situation?
Can you go ahead and break down this door or should you get a warrant or something like that?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think that certainly be reasonable, although it's not contended that that was the case here in this case.
But again, I think what's important is under Michigan v. Summers is that the Court needs to apply a reasonableness standard.
I think that's agreed among the parties here.

The specific requirements of the Fourth Amendment don't speak directly to this other than the reasonableness clause, and it's a balance between the nature of the intrusion on the one hand and the objectives served by the practice on the other hand.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does it then all boil down to the value that the media provide to law enforcement when they go into the house.
Is... is that the nub of the case?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think that's an important factor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's what we have to value against the privacy intrusion.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think that... that is the one side of the balance in all of these cases.
The other side of the balance may change.
It may be of greater concern, of lesser concern in various circumstances, but I think that's correct, Your Honor.
That would be the balance--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you say here that the value of having media coverage of this particular execution of a search warrant outweighs the privacy interests of the ranchers who were searched?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Again, we think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Whose property was searched.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --We think in the Hanlon case that's... that's correct, in particular because they were merely searching outbuildings and open areas.
They were... they were... there was a search that did not involve criminal conduct that appeared to involve any--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let's... let's assume for the moment, since it hasn't been decided, that some of these outbuildings were within the curtilage and therefore the same rules would apply as... as to the home itself.
Now, how do you weigh that balance if it... if it involves that?
Let's say a search of the home.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I think that there the fact... the fact of entering a residence is a... is obviously an important consideration.
It is... it is a consideration that raises the nature of the intrusion and magnifies it.
So, certainly that's a concern.
On the other hand--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, how... how do we weigh the balance where maybe there is in some broad sense a value to having public information about it but, on the other hand, is a very weighty interest on the part of the homeowner to have privacy within the home?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We have valued that very highly.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, how do we weigh that balance in your view?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: In our view, we would suggest that in any case where we're talking about execution of an arrest warrant, not involving a search that's going to be into private papers or personal effects, we can pretty much adopt a general rule--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But inside the home.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --That's right.
That execution of an arrest warrant is going to be generally reasonable to allow medic accompaniment because an arrest is a public event.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but I... I didn't pose arrest warrant.
I posed... which is involved in the other case... a search warrant for items executed in the home or within the curtilage.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think that it... it's fairly clear that as we proceed along a spectrum here, a search warrant in the home is more problematic than an arrest warrant.
I think it's more problematic than a search of outbuildings, certainly more problematic than a search of open fields.
Yes, and that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cordray, could... could I pursue the value to law enforcement that... that having the media along is?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I... you say in assistance of law enforcement.
I... I assume the means that to assure that everything is open and above board, that they're not being brutal, that they're not exceeding the limits of their authority.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: That's certainly much of it.
I think also there is the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is it beyond that other than PR which--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Well, the PR itself is very important.
I mean, it certainly helps to deter criminal conduct for people around the country to know that the officers are aggressively pursuing crime.
Criminals often think they're not going to be caught.
If they know that the officers are aggressively pursuing crime, they may think twice before they--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Just photographing them going into the building saying these officers are, you know, going in and... and they're going to do a search.
Do you have to be there while they're opening dresser drawers?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --No, not necessarily.
And again, that's... that has to do with the nature of the intrusion.
But standing alone--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to me the principal value you're appealing to is the value of making sure that... that law enforcement is conducted fairly and properly.
Nobody has a greater interest in that than the person being searched.
So, why don't you just ask the person, before you bring in the television news crew, you know, we're going to do you a favor.
To make sure that this--
[Laughter]
--that this search is going to be absolutely fair, we have a television crew along.
Would you like them to come in to be sure that this search will be very fair?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --They could do that, and certainly they could--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It seems to me they ought to if that's the principal value of--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Perhaps, but... but it's not a silly... it's not a silly point.
It shouldn't merely evoke laughter.
I mean, it's not as though police know ahead of time that they're going to commit an abuse or they're not going to commit an abuse.
They... they deal with unforeseen circumstances, and having the third party present may well deter abuse.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --My... my point is why don't you ask the homeowner if he wants that protection?
Why force it upon him when he'd rather... he trusts the police force and values his privacy more.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: They certainly could do that.
In... in various cases perhaps they should do that.
Whether they are obliged to do that in all cases, I guess is part of the calculus--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I... I suppose too that some sort of photographic presence might uphold the validity of the search against complaints by the... the person who's being searched.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --In fact, that was true in the Hanlon case here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are there no photographers other than those in the media?
Couldn't you bring along... I thought there were police photographers.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: There are police photographers.
They may or may not be available.
It might be within the discretion of the officer to decide, gee, we have a photographer here.
Gee, this means that might be the best way to execute it on the spot.
Typically those decisions have been left to the discretion of officials who must implement these policy--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I take it you're not arguing here that the photographers were brought along because there was no available police photographer.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --We don't know that one way or another.

Again, as a matter of objective reasonableness, the fact that their photographs or videotape could be used, as in Hanlon they were used to resolve the consent issue, may be again a part of the calculus.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Cordray, as I'm listening to your argument and you keep saying no per se rules and it depends on what the particular facts and circumstances are, I have a certain deja vu feeling, and it relates to the old days when this Court was trying to draw a luggage line, telling the police they couldn't search the... the green suitcase but they could search the paper bag, and then finally they decided in Ross, no.
The police have to know going in what they can do and what they can't do.
And your argument seems to me to be going back to the time when, well, we'll decide after the fact and there will be no rules going in.
Isn't there some real importance to being able to tell the police in advance what's okay and what isn't?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I think there is.
And as I say, this Court has never addressed this whole general area who can come with police, and so some guidance will be useful in this case.
But to draw bright lines at the outset in a... in a reasonableness balancing area might or might not be prudent.
Here I think there are certain bright lines that could be drawn.
Anytime an arrest warrant is being executed, I think in general it will be objectively reasonable to permit media to accompany and observe.
If a search warrant is being executed not in a residence, in an outer area, I think per se that probably will be acceptable to allow accompaniment.

If you have a search warrant in a home that's going to involve rummaging through private papers and personal effects, perhaps you could... you could determine as a general matter that might well be unreasonable.
I think there are some areas where clearly it would be unreasonable.

Any search involving physical invasion of the body, body cavity search or the like, just as the number of officers present in such a search is always minimized, I think any third party being present would be per se unreasonable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, we also have an issue I guess in the Hanlon case concerning audiotapes that were made that... while the officers and the media were in the house.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Correct.
There was an audiotape made of what discussion occurred as Mr. Berger and the officer were speaking to Mrs. Berger.
That's unproblematic I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Should we make any distinction between audiotapes and videotapes?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --I don't think so, Your Honor, but certainly audiotapes have been directly addressed by this Court in terms of the cases of people wearing a wire, White v. United States, Lopez, more recently Caceres, in which the Court has ultimately found there's not a constitutional problem when an individual is speaking to a government agent, even if they don't know that person to be a government agent.
Here by extension, they knew full well they were speaking to Federal agents.
I don't think there could be a reasonable expectation of privacy in those conversations.
As to whether the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your argument so far lays the groundwork for you to talk about the second question which is whether or not these principles were clearly established.
Perhaps you could address that.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Sure.
Thank you, Your Honor.
The Mitchell v. Forsyth case on qualified immunity is on all fours with this case.
There there was an allegation that the Fourth Amendment was violated.
It's a wiretapping case.
At the time of the actions, there were only two Federal decisions, both unpublished, which had upheld the legality of such conduct.
It was a fairly common practice, had been occurring episodically for 25 years.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the Fourth Amendment doesn't talk specifically about wiretapping, but it certainly talks about houses and personal effects.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: That's right.
And eventually in the Keith case, this Court ultimately resolved that such conduct was unconstitutional, but the decisions that held that postdated the events in question in the Mitchell case.
All of that is on all fours with this case here.
The only decisions at the time here had indicated that such conduct was--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn't there a distinction between going into somebody's home and... and wiretapping?
I mean, going into people's homes has been something considered questionable under the common law going... for many, many years.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.
There is... there is legal precedent that certainly makes that a harder issue in this case, and depending on how the Court rules, it may become clear now that... that this practice is unacceptable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think we can charge the officers with knowledge of Semayne's Case or the principle in Semayne's Case?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Yes, although we've... we've indicated that Semayne's Case is quite distinguishable in our brief.
In Semayne's Case it was service.

That's the British case involving service of civil process in a home, and the court itself distinguished between civil process and criminal process, which it said the public safety supersedes the private.
Blackstone echoed that and that's generally been this Court's approach, for example, and Payton recognized that an arrest warrant permits an intrusion into the home.

So, again, I think to extrapolate from older, especially British cases and early cases general principles to say that officers must have known how those apply in these specific instances would be... would be harsh, particularly given that the courts that had attempted to apply such principles had found that this conduct was... was constitutional.
And the only decisions that have ever been cited to the contrary postdated these events.
Moreover, if this were an unusual practice, if it had not been engaged in except very occasionally around the country, that might explain the lack of this--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They might have questioned how frequently it's done.
You rely heavily on the Marshals Service policy.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Not only that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you do rely on that heavily, do you not?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: We do, but the Fletcher case--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let me just ask you a question about the Marshals--

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Can you point to me the part of the policy that makes it clear they could take people into the home?
I didn't find that in what cited to me.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: Page 7 of the joint appendix in the Wilson case contemplates that there may be occasion.
It says, if the arrest is planned to take place inside a house or building, agree ahead of time when the camera can enter and who will get the signal.
That isn't an express authorization in all circumstances to take media into a home, but it certainly contemplates that a... a rule that would say you can never allow the camera and the media--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I thought the sheriff, the Montgomery County Sheriff, in his deposition testified that permitting civilians to enter a home during the execution of a warrant wasn't permitted there.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --That was... that was his view and that may be his policy.
There are a variety of policies around the country.
I think it's important--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that might have been clearly established at least in Montgomery County.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --Well, I... I don't think so, given that... given that the case law at the time did not clearly establish it, and judges since have... have disagreed, you know.
And this was a practice that was common.

We point to the Fletcher case from the Florida Supreme Court which recognized this as a common practice at the common law as of 1972, and the Prahl case on remand to trial court in Wisconsin found this to be a common practice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, in Wilson v. Layne, the facts were... were pretty extreme in terms of an invasion of privacy in the home.
It occurred in the early hours of the morning when the couple were asleep and were not, you know, adequately dressed.
I mean, it was an amazing invasion.
And you think on that balance that we would not be concerned about the privacy interests in that situation simply because it was an arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I think certainly the Court would be concerned.
I think the fact that it's an arrest warrant weighs in the balance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you think we should have a clear rule that in executing an arrest warrant, you can take outsiders in who aren't there to help with the execution of the arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: I would tend to suggest a more fact-specific approach to these cases, but if the desire is to draw some bright lines, that may be one that could be.
If I could--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That might be a very easy clear line to draw.

turn.speaker: richard_a_cordray
turn.label: Mr. Richard A. Cordray
turn.text: --It could be.
If I could reserve the remainder of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Cordray.
Mr. Fletcher-Hill, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
There are two fundamental facts that establish the qualified immunity of the three deputy sheriffs I represent.

The first of those is that the most able lawyer researching this issue in 1992 would have found no cases from any court condemning the mere presence of media when a warrant is executed lawfully as a constitutional violation.
The only cases then in existence, in fact, held to the contrary, that media presence at most was a tort under common law principles if... if the media was brought inside a home.
The second point is that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask... suppose it had been clearly established that it was a common law tort to bring the media into a home, but there had been no decision on interpreting section 1983 or the Fourteenth Amendment.
Would you think under those... under that assumption there would be qualified immunity?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
I think it would still be an open question whether... whether this Court would eventually incorporate those common law principles into the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, assume that... assume that we on the first time we... we decide yes, it's a clear violation.
The only issue we have to face is, should the officers have been aware that they shouldn't go in if their only restraint on going in was a well-established common law rule... a common law tort rule.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: No, because the... the doctrine of qualified immunity would operate only as to the constitutional principles.

There may be other immunities for the officers concerning the common law, and in fact, one... one could find the situation where the common law would... would suggest to these officers that they should not do this.
But as a matter of Fourth Amendment jurisprudence and the Bivens or 1983 action against the officers, I think the law would still not be clearly established as a matter of constitutional principle.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Don't you think it's a clearly established constitutional principle that it is unreasonable to commit a tort in... in the course of the search?
I mean, once you... I mean, I think it's an open question of whether... whether it was clear that this was a tort, but if it was a tort, I think the game is up.
Surely you're not authorized to commit a tort in the course of a search.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wouldn't that make the search automatically unreasonable?
Do you need a case that says that?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Let me give an... an illustration.
The technical issue of trespass may be such that in the absence of a warrant, something would clearly be a trespass.

But if the officer is in the position under Fourth Amendment jurisprudence of having authority to come into the house based on a warrant, then that potential superior authority of the officer would overcome the tort violation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, supposing you... you have... during a search or an arrest an officer commits what's later decided to have been an assault and battery.
You... you run up against the person in a way a court says there wasn't... that wouldn't make it invalid under the Fourth Amendment, would it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: That's correct.

You... you would still have the issue under the Fourth Amendment, but whether that use of force, which might admittedly be... be a battery at common law, is justified by the need to control, under Michigan v. Summers, the people who are in the... the premises where the warrant is being executed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There occurs to me an even better answer than that which is that the open fields doctrine explicitly says that you can commit a tort and not violate the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, in many cases the... the tort issue and the constitutional issue are going to overlap very closely.
But in fact, this case, the Wilson case, provides a good illustration of where they don't overlap and where I think there's an important distinction.
The common law has arisen in the area of invasion of privacy to take care of situations of publication.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's true.
But would you take me through the officer's thinking, the thinking of the reasonable officer?
He knows that the Fourth Amendment protects the security of a person in his house against an unreasonable search.
He knows that.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He knows a police officer normally has to get a warrant... normally... before he can go into that house in order to protect that privacy.
He has to have a very good reason to intrude on that privacy.

Now, a person knowing that... why wouldn't he think, well, obviously you can't bring in a person who isn't even mentioned in the warrant, which person is going to broadcast personal things to 10 million people?
I mean, if the lesser is forbidden, why isn't it obvious that the greater is?
And so, what I... what I want you to do is to explain what's the thinking of a person who knows the lesser is forbidden, but nonetheless he thinks it's reasonable to do the greater.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Your Honor, the... the thinking of the officers in this case is that, of course, it is a serious proposition to enter someone's house without consent to make an arrest, but these officers had, matching that issue, valid arrest warrants which they knew gave them clear authority to enter the house.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It couldn't... it couldn't be more important to broadcast this than it is to do the search in the first place.
So, why wouldn't you at least have to have it in the warrant?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: No.
The... Your Honor, I think the entry into the house is met by the presence of the warrant.
The secondary--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the warrant refer to the... they have a right under the warrant to bring in the press?
Does it say anything about the press?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --No.
I think the issue of the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In fact... if I may interrupt... doesn't the warrant say just the contrary?
Doesn't the warrant expressly limit itself to officials, to police officers of some sort?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --Your Honor, that's correct.
The warrant is directed to peace officers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay.
So, the terms of the warrant limit it to peace officers.

How could an officer therefore reasonably believe that under the authority of that warrant he could take in other people regardless of what the general law might be if the warrant were less exact in specifying those to... to whom it gave authority?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: These officers could believe that because at the time they operated, they were operating under the direction of the Marshals Service.
The media presence was--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but there was a Federal statute I believe in effect at the time.

It may still be in effect as far as I know in 18 U.S. Code 3105, and it says, a search warrant may in all cases be served by any of the officers mentioned in its direction or by an officer authorized by law to serve such warrant, but by no other person, except in aid of the officer on his requiring it, he being present and acting in its execution.
Now, how do you read that statute as allowing private citizens or media ride-alongs?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --If applicable at all, that statute would be applicable only to the Hanlon case which was a search warrant and not to the officers here who were executing an arrest warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I suppose it isn't the fact that the statute limits the number of people who can serve the warrant, doesn't in so many words say that nobody else can come along.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: That's correct.
And we have made no claim here that... that the media are entitled to help serve the warrant.
The officers must stay within the clear bounds of their authority under the warrant in serving it.
The media there... are there as mere observers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if... if... if we take the word serve to mean those who may in fact be present, then I take it you're... you're out of luck.
There's no basis for... for arguing qualified immunity because there's no basis for... for arguing any colorable authority.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think a great deal of authority has... has come down to... for the proposition that non-law enforcement personnel may be present during the service of both search warrants and arrest warrants without--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, you're arguing that cases from... from other States which... which may have condoned this in the past override the terms of your warrant in deciding what it is reasonable for your officers to do.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --No.
The terms of this warrant only say that a... a peace officer is to execute the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: And peace officers in this case in fact did execute the warrant.
The... the media personnel did not do anything to execute the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I... I... if... if we... if it is reasonable to read it as excluding others from participating in the execution of the warrant, then I take it by its terms your... your argument would be excluded.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: It would exclude on the substantive violation, but I don't think it would exclude the issue of clearly established right because it would still be the case that these officers armed with those warrants would be operating under a Marshals Service policy arranged at the direction of others whom they did not have a reason to question and regular on its face, that is, the media participation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Their argument basically is the Marshals Service told us we could do it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --No.
At the time that these officers acted, it was... it was a common law enforcement practice to have ride-alongs.
There was no contrary authority from any court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but when... when you say ride-along, are you saying that it was a common law enforcement practice to bring the media into the house in the execution of an arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --I... I think the existence of a number of cases where exactly that happened--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but in Wilson v. Layne, we know what the Montgomery County Sheriff said, and he said it wasn't the policy.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: --That's true, and I think if anything, those statements by Sheriff Kight illustrate the predicament of these officers because what Sheriff Kight also said was as to this operation, he understood his own officers to be operating under Marshals Service guidelines which did permit this activity, and he himself would not condemn the conduct of his own officers at... at this time in 1992 because they were on loan to the Marshals Service and not operating under his own office's policies.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, were they on loan in the sense that they were required to follow orders from the Marshals Service?
You spoke of their predicament, and I'm not sure that I know what the predicament is.
Were they... had they taken some kind of an oath to do what the Marshals Service told them to?

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: In fact, two of them were... were deputized for purposes... as deputy U.S. marshals for purposes of this operation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, they were subject to line authority.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: The... the authority under that program was directed from Mr. Layne, from Deputy U.S. Marshal Layne, as the supervisor in... in this geographic area.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Fletcher-Hill.

turn.speaker: lawrence_r_fletcher_hill
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence R. Fletcher-Hill
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Rossbacher, we'll hear from you.
Is it Rossbacher or bacher?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Rossbacher, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Rossbacher.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The searches and seizures involved in the Berger case violate the core values and the core holdings of this Court in relation to the Fourth Amendment in five important ways.
First, the warrant was used as a general warrant, bringing private persons onto private property to search and seize for their private purposes.
The Revolution was fought, in part, to prohibit that.
Second, the conduct of the law enforcement officers in bringing the media, the private persons, on was not authorized by the warrant.
Their presence was not authorized.

In fact, their presence which had been guaranteed by an Assistant U.S. Attorney signing a contract on behalf of the Government a week before the warrants were obtained was concealed from the magistrate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it your position that if the warrant does not specifically authorize people other than peace officers to serve it that no such person can be brought along?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: That is in part our position, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even if it were, for instance, a search warrant in connection with a... a theft ring and the owner of the property was brought along to identify the goods or some expert in fingerprinting was brought along or something like that?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: We are not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say absolutely not.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
We think that 3105... I hadn't finished my answer.
I beg my... I beg your pardon.

We believe 3105... as Sir Matthew Hale's Pleas to the Court in 1600 said, you can bring a private person along as long as he is under the authority of the law enforcement officer and is there solely to execute the warrant and for that function.
Here it is undisputed that that did not occur.
In fact, the media--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --had signed a contract--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Just a minute, Mr.--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --In... in answer to my question, you say that a person such as Justice O'Connor described could be brought along.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that it's not... not necessary to authorize it in the warrant.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: The warrant authorizes, as we understand it under section 3105 and the Fourth Amendment, law enforcement to bring along pursuant to that explicit authorization, which we believe is a constitutional authorization, people who are necessary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the warrant doesn't say anything about... typically it doesn't.
It authorizes certain police officers to... to execute the warrant.

And we're interested in exploring whether under your view other people brought in by the officers to help them identify goods, to take fingerprints, whatever it might be, to take photographs for them, for the police... now, is that all right even though they are not explicitly named in the warrant and although the warrant doesn't talk about such people?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, because the warrant is issued in the context of section 3105 being--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about the attorney in the Hanlon case who went along?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --We do not believe the attorney was authorized.
The testimony below and in the record is unequivocal that he performed no role in the search, and in fact, the evidence obtained from CNN--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say authorize, Mr. Rossbacher.
What do you mean by the word authorize?
Do you mean permitted under the Fourth Amendment or specifically authorized in some other way?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Either.
Both, Your Honor.
In fact, he was a stranger to the performance of the warrant.
He was there to give a press conference, according to the materials we obtained from CNN, for making a TV show.
He was not there to perform any law enforcement function related to the service and execution of the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if he had been there to perform a law enforcement function, it would have been all right?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: If he had been designated as necessary by the executing agent under 3105--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, now, where... where does all that come from?
You say designated.
That's all under 3105?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

And under the unanimous cases that we've cited in our brief construing section 3105 from the circuits, Schwimmer, Clouston, all of these, the 3105 authorizes the executing agent to bring along a private person who is necessary, provided they are necessary and provided their activities are confined to execution of the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the law students in... in the clinic, in the law school clinic, as part of their educational program are riding along with the police, going in with the police wherever they go?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: I'm not aware, Your Honor, that they do go in with police wherever they go.
We do not believe that people who are there just to observe and not performing an essential task--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what... what can in your... in your view, consistent with the Fourth Amendment, what can the academic, the student, do in the way of a ride-along?
What would... what would the limits be?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --They cannot enter pursuant to a search warrant or an arrest warrant into private property where the warrant is necessary.
The authority of the warrant... or the specific police power of the law enforcement officer is necessary to enter the property.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm giving you an example of a person who isn't there to identify anything.
He's not to aid the police.
He's there to be educated, to observe, and to advance his own education.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: We believe that's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And so, I'd like to know... he's in the squad car, such a person.
Can he ever leave the car, or he's just waiting for the police as they go in and out to search, to seize?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Presumably he can leave the car.
He cannot enter private property pursuant to the authority given to the police by the warrant.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Just a slight variation on Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical.
Suppose... just assume this is right, but the... the optimum number of police for a search is... of a house is five.
But they bring along two police trainees, and they say, now, you just watch.
Is that permitted?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Not if they're just watching, Your Honor.
If they are there to execute the warrant and it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, they're not there... they're there just for training purposes.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Then it is our view--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, the police have no way to train their... train their new recruits, their... their rookies.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Not on private property, Your Honor, not in violation of the privacy rights and the core values protected by the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, you say private property.
How about the entry onto the ranch lands in Hanlon?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Your Honor, there was no--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Armed with a warrant.
Now, is there any violation of the Fourth Amendment by virtue of strangers to the execution of the warrant accompanying the officers on the open lands in... in Hanlon?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --We believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And what do you rely on for that?
Because there... we have cases dealing with a so-called open fields exception.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: I know you do, Your Honor.
I don't think that that... when you're in the open fields it is... it is clearly established as to what can be done there.
But what is clearly established is that no authority of the warrant can be used to justify private parties.
What's happening here... and I would like to correct a misstatement that I'll get to as to what was done with this warrant.
The warrant was represented to cover everything, including the house.

The press was brought along solely... and they have said this... solely on the authority of law enforcement officers to enter and, in essence, be immune from their... the consequences of their conduct under the open fields doctrine.
As a result, we believe that that's improper, and that does violate the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I think the balance may well be different within a home or within closed structures in the curtilage than it is in open areas where presumably anyone, the mailman or anybody else, can drive up to the ranch house but can't enter the house.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Your Honor, there is a problem with that and that is that in this case, CNN asserts that it has an absolute defense to charges against trespass, charges against any kind of tortious conduct because of the permission given by law enforcement to enter.
Their... their position is not that the First Amendment allowed them to do this.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But we don't have that question before us.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: No, but it... it is problematical in that what law enforcement is doing here is, in fact, facilitating a tort explicitly.
They're attempting to immunize a tort.
And we think that that's inappropriate and improper and violates the Fourth Amendment.
In addition, it's not possible to argue that this was not clearly established.

Section 3105 and the cases that interpret it have said clearly for years that in fact law enforcement officers are not free to bring strangers to the warrant on private property except for the purposes of 3105.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The... the problem with that in your case is the open fields doctrine might mean that the rules here are not so well established.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Your Honor, let us look--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's a murky doctrine.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --But let us look at what happened here.
First, they entered the house pursuant to the claim that the warrant covered the house.
That was what triggered the entry.
There was no consent.
The officers have testified there was no consent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The Ninth Circuit--
--Well, the lower courts have decide... the Ninth Circuit said there was.
And we're not going to--
--We... we don't reevaluate those things here.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: There was no factual finding of consent.
It was not litigated below in the district--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The court of appeals said there was consent.
So, take it... take it from us--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --I understand.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --we're not interested.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Even if there was consent, the position is that they could not bring in the press with a microphone to seize conversations protected by Silverman and these cases and Katz in the house, which is what was done.
It was done on 9 or 10 separate occasions.
They taped solely... law enforcement did not tape.
The tapes were not made available to law enforcement.
They were not in their possession, either video or oral tapes.
They were, in fact, refused to be produced in the criminal trial, and the Government in fact even refused to admit there was a contract here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you agree, Mr. Rossbacher, that the agents did not search when they were in... when they were in the home?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: No.
They... they entered the house under a claim that they had a right to search the house, and they in fact went through the house, and they recorded in the house.
And we believe that is a search and a seizure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, apart from... apart from the recording, is it your--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: We believe that there--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --contention that they... that they conducted a search of the house?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --Your Honor, they entered the house and observed what was there.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I mean, I... I have a lot of people come into my house.
I don't think everybody who comes into my house is searching my house.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Your Honor, when they say that they're entering pursuant to a search warrant and they assert their absolute right to do that, when they enter--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That... that's out of the case as the Chief Justice has said.
We assume--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --I understand.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --that they entered pursuant to consent.
Having entered pursuant to consent, did they search?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: We believe so, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In... in any respect other than making the recording?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: They went through the rooms, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I didn't ask whether they went through the rooms.
People who come into my house go through the rooms.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: They did not tear the place apart, Your Honor.
They went through the rooms--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They didn't search.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --I don't believe, Your Honor, it's fair to say that when a law enforcement officer enters your house pursuant to a search warrant and a claim of right, that in fact he's not searching when he observes what he observes there and was free to testify about it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If it was a search, does your position imply that... suppose they had found something in the house... that that evidence would have to be suppressed?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Absolutely, Your Honor, that in fact, under Bumpers and under Schneckloth, in fact, having asserted on the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: My assumption is that it would have been all warranted because they did have a warrant.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --The warrant excluded--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Were it not for the media... so, in other words, I'm giving you a situation where the police had just gone in on their own, executed the warrant, they would have... they would have done everything according to law.
That bringing the media along you say makes it unlawful.
And my question is, to what extent do you go... does the media presence so taint the operation that what would otherwise have been lawfully seized becomes unlawfully seized?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --If the media seized it, as they did with the recordings, we believe it is like the extra mikes installed in the house.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not the media.
The police... the police did--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: The police seized--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --but they did it in the presence of the photographers who got it all live for CNN.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --We think it makes the search unreasonable, but we're not sure that it triggers the exclusionary rule because in fact what would be found would be found properly by the officers.
You're really talking more I believe with respect about the operation of the exclusionary rule.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, you're... so, you're now giving me a different answer than the one you gave me initially.
You say--

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: I hope not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, you told me I thought initially... or maybe I didn't phrase the question so that you were able to answer it precisely.
I asked you would the exclusionary rule apply to evidence seized under a warrant but in the presence of the press and captured on... on the press camera.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: Captured on the press camera, the press tape we believe would be... would be suppressed.
And officer's testimony as to him finding the evidence or the evidence itself would not be because that would not be in excess of the warrant, as you phrased your question to me, as I understand it.
But the seizure by the press, just as if the press wandered off by themselves into a shed and found evidence and seized it, would clearly be--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the evidence found by the police might fall within the inevitable discovery exception.
I mean, they're going to go in with a warrant and find what they find, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --It might well, Your Honor.
It might be a hard argument to make if in fact the press goes off and... and films things and the police doesn't bother to look there and then later the tape shows it.
I mean, that would be a situation--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, no.
The assumption we were talking about was officers with a warrant finding the evidence and nonetheless having the presence of the media.

turn.speaker: henry_h_rossbacher
turn.label: Mr. Henry H. Rossbacher
turn.text: --We don't think that that per se triggers the exclusionary rule, but we think that it is a general warrant.

We think it violates the Fourth Amendment, and we think that the private electronic... private electronic surveillance that took place here by the CNN is a separate search by a private party for their private purposes, the proceeds of which is not properly seized by the Government.
The cases of this Court involving the extent of a search, for example, Arizona v. Hicks and Andresen, we believe should inform the Court's consideration of what happened here.
The Court has been eternally vigilant and jealous of confining law enforcement officers to what is explicitly authorized.
For example, you can't turn over a Bang and Olafson box.
